outbound.origin: Major US City (e.g., New York JFK/EWR - assumed as no origin provided)
outbound.notes: Prices are estimates for economy class round-trip flights for 3 travelers, subject to availability and booking time. Booking well in advance (ideally 6-9 months out) is crucial, especially approaching the holiday season. Direct flights for this duration and number of travelers are likely to consume the entire $3000 budget.

return.destination: Major US City (e.g., New York JFK/EWR - assumed)

carRental.dailyRateEstimated: $40 - $60 (excluding insurance, fuel, tolls, and parking fees)
carRental.notes: Renting a car for the entire duration (27 days) is generally not recommended for a trip focused on Paris due to heavy traffic, expensive and scarce parking, and the city's excellent public transportation system. Furthermore, at an estimated daily rate, a 27-day rental would exceed $1000-$1600, which is not feasible given the $3000 total budget that flights alone are expected to consume. A car might be considered for specific day trips outside Paris if the budget is significantly increased, or if you manage to secure flights at the absolute lowest end of the estimate.

options: Paris Metro: Extensive subway system, the most efficient way to navigate within the city.
RER (Regional Express Network): Commuter rail connecting Paris with its suburbs and major airports (CDG, Orly).
Buses: Good for shorter distances, scenic routes, and areas not covered by Metro.
Trams: Serve outer districts and connect suburbs.
passesAndTickets: Navigo Découverte: Weekly (Monday to Sunday) or monthly pass, best value for longer stays. Requires a photo. The Zone 1-5 pass covers all major attractions and airports.
Mobilis Ticket: Daily pass for specific zones.
T+ Ticket: Single journey ticket, valid for Metro, RER (within Paris), bus, and tram. Can be bought in a 'carnet' (pack of 10) for a slight discount.
Paris Visite Pass: Tourist pass for 1, 2, 3, or 5 consecutive days, offers discounts to some attractions. Often more expensive than Navigo for extended stays.

rideSharing.availability: Widely available throughout Paris and surrounding areas.
rideSharing.notes: Convenient for late nights, direct travel with luggage, or when public transit is less practical. However, it is generally more expensive than public transit for daily commuting, and surge pricing applies during peak hours or high demand.

localTransportation.generalRecommendation: Given your budget constraints and the excellent public transport network in Paris, it is strongly recommended to rely primarily on the Metro and RER. A Navigo Découverte pass will offer the best value for your nearly month-long stay. Ride-sharing should be reserved for specific needs like airport transfers or late-night travel.

accommodation.description: A stylish hostel offering private rooms, a rooftop terrace with city views, and a lively bar. Located in the trendy 10th arrondissement near Canal Saint-Martin, it's perfect for travelers seeking a social atmosphere, vibrant nightlife, and easy access to diverse food options and metro lines for urban adventures.

Situated directly on the picturesque Canal Saint-Martin, this lively hostel offers comfortable private rooms. Its popular on-site bar and restaurant make it a hub for nightlife and meeting fellow travelers. Excellent public transport links provide adventurous exploration of Paris's culinary scene.

A modern and trendy hostel in the authentic Belleville district, known for its vibrant street art, diverse food scene, and lively bars. It features a fantastic rooftop bar with panoramic views, ideal for enjoying Parisian nightlife, and comfortable private rooms for a unique adventure in a local neighborhood.

This contemporary hostel is nestled in the energetic Belleville district, offering an immersive Parisian experience. With a focus on community, it provides comfortable private rooms, a bar, restaurant, and a communal kitchen, perfect for food enthusiasts. Its location is great for exploring local nightlife and adventurous strolls through unique markets.

A straightforward, budget-friendly hotel in the heart of the lively 11th arrondissement. It offers clean, basic private rooms and is surrounded by countless restaurants, bars, and cafes, making it an excellent base for nightlife and food exploration, with good metro access for city adventures.

attractions.name: Eiffel Tower
attractions.bestTime: Sunset or evening for sparkling lights and city views

attractions.name: The Catacombs of Paris
attractions.bestTime: Morning on a weekday to avoid peak crowds

attractions.name: Montmartre & Sacré-Cœur Basilica
attractions.cost: Free (Basilica entry), Funicular is metro ticket price
attractions.bestTime: Late afternoon to early evening for sunset views and exploring artistic streets

attractions.name: Parisian Food Tour (e.g., Le Marais or Latin Quarter)
Fontainebleau Forest (Day Trip)
attractions.cost: Train ticket ~€10-15 one way, Château entry ~€13, forest free
attractions.bestTime: Any sunny day, spring or autumn are ideal for hiking/bouldering

attractions.name: Canal Saint-Martin
attractions.cost: Free to explore, cost for food/drinks
attractions.bestTime: Late afternoon to evening for a stroll, trendy bars, and waterfront dining

attractions.name: Arc de Triomphe (Climb to the top)
attractions.bestTime: Sunset for panoramic views of the Champs-Élysées and sparkling Eiffel Tower

restaurants.name: Le Relais de l'Entrecôte
restaurants.specialty: Serving only one main dish: perfectly cooked steak with their famous secret sauce and unlimited fries.

restaurants.name: Frenchie
restaurants.specialty: Inventive, seasonal dishes with a focus on fresh, high-quality ingredients in a cozy, sought-after setting.

restaurants.name: Chez Janou
restaurants.specialty: Vibrant, bustling atmosphere, an extensive collection of pastis, and a legendary, all-you-can-eat chocolate mousse.

restaurants.name: Bistrot Paul Bert
restaurants.specialty: Authentic Parisian bistro experience known for hearty, traditional dishes like steak au poivre and fresh seafood.

restaurants.name: L'As du Fallafel
restaurants.specialty: Widely regarded as serving the best falafel sandwich in Paris, a true local institution in the Marais.

restaurants.name: Septime
restaurants.specialty: A Michelin-starred restaurant offering an innovative, nature-inspired tasting menu with a focus on sustainable, seasonal ingredients.
mustTry: The Carte Blanche (tasting menu which changes daily based on seasonal availability)

activities.morning: Arrive in Paris, check into your accommodation, and settle in.
activities.afternoon: Take a leisurely stroll around your immediate neighborhood to get acquainted with local amenities and soak in the Parisian atmosphere.
activities.evening: Enjoy a casual dinner at a local bistro or café. Consider a relaxed evening exploring your arrondissement.

activities.morning: Visit Notre Dame Cathedral (exterior view and current reconstruction progress) and explore the charming Île de la Cité, including Sainte-Chapelle with its stunning stained glass.
activities.afternoon: Wander through the historic Latin Quarter, explore its bookstores (like Shakespeare and Company), and soak in the vibrant student atmosphere.
activities.evening: Dinner at **Chez Janou** (Provençal French), known for its bustling atmosphere and legendary chocolate mousse.

activities.morning: Explore the Trocadéro gardens for iconic views of the Eiffel Tower, then walk down to the Champ de Mars.
activities.afternoon: Visit Les Invalides (home to Napoleon's tomb and the Army Museum) or Musée du Quai Branly - Jacques Chirac (Indigenous Arts Museum).
activities.evening: Experience the **Eiffel Tower** at sunset or in the evening to see its sparkling lights. Afterwards, have dinner in the 7th arrondissement.

activities.morning: Head to **The Catacombs of Paris** (book online in advance for a weekday morning to avoid peak crowds). Allow 1.5-2 hours.
activities.afternoon: Relax and stroll through the beautiful Luxembourg Gardens, then explore the elegant Saint-Germain-des-Prés neighborhood.
activities.evening: Dinner at **Le Relais de l'Entrecôte** (Steak Frites), a unique Parisian institution famous for its single-item menu.

activities.morning: Dedicate your morning to the world-renowned Louvre Museum (pre-book your timed entry ticket).
activities.afternoon: Stroll through the tranquil Palais Royal gardens and arcade, then explore the upscale boutiques of Rue Saint-Honoré.
activities.evening: Enjoy dinner in the 1st arrondissement, perhaps near Les Halles or the Palais Royal area.

activities.morning: Embark on a **Parisian Food Tour** (e.g., Le Marais or Saint-Germain-des-Prés) to discover local culinary delights and specialties.
activities.afternoon: Continue exploring Le Marais: visit Place des Vosges, wander through its historic streets, and discover unique boutiques and art galleries.
activities.evening: For a casual but iconic meal, grab a falafel sandwich from **L'As du Fallafel** in Le Marais, or choose another charming Marais bistro.

activities.morning: Enjoy a leisurely morning, perhaps visiting a local market for fresh produce or revisiting a favorite café.
activities.afternoon: Take a relaxing **Seine River cruise** to see many of Paris's landmarks from a different perspective.
activities.evening: A relaxed dinner, maybe trying out a neighborhood restaurant near your accommodation.

activities.morning: Explore the vibrant streets of Pigalle, see the 'Wall of Love' (Le Mur des Je t'aime), and soak in the bohemian atmosphere.
activities.afternoon: Spend the late afternoon to early evening exploring **Montmartre & Sacré-Cœur Basilica**. Climb to the top for sunset views, wander the artistic streets of Place du Tertre.
activities.evening: Experience the legendary **Moulin Rouge Cabaret Show**. Consider the dinner and show option for a full evening experience (booking essential).

activities.morning: Visit the magnificent Musée d'Orsay, housed in a former railway station, famous for its Impressionist and Post-Impressionist masterpieces.
activities.afternoon: Explore the elegant shops and art galleries of Saint-Germain-des-Prés, perhaps stopping for coffee at a historic café like Les Deux Magots.
activities.evening: Dinner at **Bistrot Paul Bert** (classic French bistro), known for its authentic Parisian experience and hearty dishes like Steak au Poivre. Reservations highly recommended.

activities.morning: Visit the Grand Palais and Petit Palais (often free entry for permanent collections), beautiful architectural gems on either side of Pont Alexandre III.
activities.afternoon: Stroll down the iconic Champs-Élysées, doing some window shopping or visiting flagship stores.
activities.evening: Climb to the top of the **Arc de Triomphe** for panoramic sunset views of Paris and the sparkling Eiffel Tower. Dinner near the Champs-Élysées or Etoile area.

activities.morning: Take a full-day trip to **Fontainebleau Forest & Château**. Catch a train from Gare de Lyon to Fontainebleau-Avon. Explore the magnificent château.
activities.afternoon: Spend time hiking or bouldering in the vast Fontainebleau Forest. Pack a picnic or enjoy lunch in the town of Fontainebleau.
activities.evening: Return to Paris for a relaxed dinner after a day in the countryside.

activities.morning: Explore the dynamic area around Place de la République, then wander through the trendy boutiques and concept stores nearby.
activities.afternoon: Stroll along **Canal Saint-Martin**, enjoying the locks, bridges, and charming waterfront. It's a great spot for people-watching.
activities.evening: Enjoy dinner at one of the many cool bars and restaurants lining Canal Saint-Martin or in the vibrant 10th/11th arrondissements.

activities.morning: Free morning to revisit a favorite spot, explore a new local market, or simply enjoy a slow Parisian breakfast.
activities.afternoon: Indulge in some shopping at the grand department stores like Galeries Lafayette or Printemps, marveling at their architecture and domes.
activities.evening: Discover a new restaurant in a different arrondissement, perhaps one recommended by locals.

activities.morning: Visit the modern art collections at Centre Pompidou or explore the intimate Picasso Museum in Le Marais.
activities.afternoon: Walk through the Jardin des Tuileries, connecting the Louvre to Place de la Concorde, admiring the sculptures and fountains.
activities.evening: Dinner in the area surrounding Les Halles or back in Le Marais.

activities.morning: Explore the picturesque Parc des Buttes-Chaumont, a hilly park with a lake, waterfall, and temple, offering great city views.
activities.afternoon: Wander through the charming village-like streets of the Butte-aux-Cailles neighborhood in the 13th arrondissement.
activities.evening: Try for a reservation at **Frenchie** (Modern French), a highly sought-after restaurant known for its inventive tasting menu. Book *far* in advance, otherwise explore other modern French bistros.

activities.morning: Deep dive into a specific arrondissement you've enjoyed, perhaps Saint-Germain-des-Prés or Le Marais, exploring side streets and hidden courtyards.
activities.afternoon: Visit the Marché des Enfants Rouges, Paris's oldest covered market, for a variety of food stalls and a casual lunch.
activities.evening: Enjoy a relaxed evening with dinner at a charming local restaurant, soaking in the Parisian ambiance.

activities.morning: Embark on a self-guided patisserie tour, sampling croissants, macarons, and other French pastries from various bakeries.
activities.afternoon: Participate in a French wine or cheese tasting experience to deepen your appreciation for local culinary traditions.
activities.evening: Dine at a restaurant specializing in a regional French cuisine you haven't tried yet, or a highly-rated bistro you've discovered.

activities.morning: Visit the impressive Panthéon, a neoclassical mausoleum containing the remains of distinguished French citizens. Explore the surrounding Latin Quarter.
activities.afternoon: Stroll down Rue Mouffetard, one of Paris's oldest and liveliest market streets, then relax at the historic Arènes de Lutèce (Roman amphitheater).
activities.evening: Enjoy dinner in the vibrant Latin Quarter, with its wide array of international and traditional French eateries.

activities.morning: Visit the Rodin Museum, admiring his famous sculptures like 'The Thinker' and 'The Kiss' in a beautiful garden setting.
activities.afternoon: Relax in the peaceful Jardin des Plantes, Paris's main botanical garden, which also houses a small zoo and natural history museum.
activities.evening: A quiet evening with dinner, perhaps trying a restaurant in a neighborhood you've enjoyed revisiting.

activities.morning: Explore the beautiful Parc Monceau, known for its picturesque follies and elegant pathways, a favorite spot for Parisian families.
activities.afternoon: Take a cooking class focusing on French cuisine, learning to prepare classic dishes and desserts.
activities.evening: Enjoy the fruits of your labor from the cooking class, or have dinner out, discussing your new culinary skills.

activities.morning: Discover the charm of Montparnasse, including the Montparnasse Tower for alternative panoramic views (optional) and the famous cemeteries.
activities.afternoon: Explore the vibrant street art and bohemian vibe of the Belleville neighborhood, or relax at a traditional Parisian café.
activities.evening: Dine at a restaurant in the Montparnasse area, known for its historic brasseries.

activities.morning: Wander through some of Paris's beautiful covered passages (Passages Couverts) like Galerie Vivienne or Passage des Panoramas, filled with unique shops and cafés.
activities.afternoon: Take a guided tour of the Opéra Garnier (Palais Garnier), marveling at its opulent architecture and famous grand staircase.
activities.evening: Dinner in the Opéra district, which offers a range of dining options from elegant restaurants to casual brasseries.

activities.morning: Explore the massive Les Puces de Saint-Ouen (flea market), one of the largest in the world, if it's a weekend (Sat-Mon).
activities.afternoon: Continue exploring the flea market for unique treasures, or if not a market day, visit the Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie.
activities.evening: Enjoy a relaxed dinner in a neighborhood like Saint-Ouen or explore dining options near the Porte de Clignancourt.

activities.morning: Revisit a museum or neighborhood that you particularly enjoyed, or explore a new area of Paris you haven't yet discovered.
activities.afternoon: Enjoy a final long lunch at a beautiful Parisian brasserie, savoring the atmosphere and the food.
activities.evening: Indulge in a special farewell dinner. If you couldn't get into **Frenchie** before, try again, or choose another high-end restaurant for a memorable last meal.

activities.morning: Take a leisurely photo walk through a picturesque area of Paris, capturing your favorite sights and moments.
activities.afternoon: Do some last-minute souvenir shopping, finding unique gifts and mementos to take home.
activities.evening: A final classic Parisian dinner. Perhaps revisit **Le Relais de l'Entrecôte** for its iconic steak frites or **Bistrot Paul Bert** for a hearty bistro experience.

activities.morning: Enjoy a relaxed morning, perhaps a final visit to a favorite café or a gentle stroll through a local park.
activities.afternoon: Pack your bags and prepare for departure, taking time to reflect on your Parisian adventure.
activities.evening: A light and easy dinner, perhaps ordering in or a casual meal at a nearby eatery.

activities.morning: Enjoy a final Parisian breakfast. Check out from your accommodation.
activities.afternoon: Depart from Paris, taking with you wonderful memories of your extensive stay.

localTips: Always greet shopkeepers, cafe staff, and even strangers you interact with using 'Bonjour' (or 'Bonsoir' after dusk) and a 'Merci, au revoir' when leaving. It's a fundamental courtesy that goes a long way.
The Metro is your best friend for getting around Paris. Purchase a 'carnet' of 10 tickets for convenience and a slight discount, and always validate your ticket before boarding.
Be highly aware of pickpockets, especially in crowded tourist areas like the Eiffel Tower, Louvre, Montmartre, and on the Metro. Keep bags securely closed and valuables out of sight.
Credit and debit cards are widely accepted. Tipping is appreciated but generally not expected to be as high as in the US; rounding up the bill or leaving a few euros for good service is common.
Visit major attractions like the Louvre, Eiffel Tower, and Notre Dame area either right at opening time or in the late evening to avoid the largest crowds and long queues.
Learn a few basic French phrases: 'Bonjour' (hello), 'Merci' (thank you), 'S'il vous plaît' (please), 'Pardon' (excuse me). Parisians appreciate the effort, even if you switch to English afterward.
Pack comfortable walking shoes – you'll walk miles exploring the city's charming streets. Also bring layers as Parisian weather can be unpredictable, and a universal travel adapter.
For a more authentic experience, explore beyond the main tourist hubs. Wander through the Marais, visit a local market like Marché des Enfants Rouges, or enjoy a picnic along the Canal Saint-Martin.
